The CDC has updated it's information this last September, and the finding don't look good for homosexual relationships. * A recent CDC study found that in 2008 one in five (19%) MSM in 21 major US cities were infected with HIV, and nearly half (44%) were unaware of their infection. In this study, 28% of black MSM were HIV-infected, compared to 18% of Hispanic/Latino MSM and 16% of white MSM. Other racial/ethnic groups of MSM also have high numbers of HIV infections, including American Indian/Alaska Native MSM (20%) and Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander MSM (18%).
 * In 2007, MSM were 44 to 86 times as likely to be diagnosed with HIV compared with other men, and 40 to 77 times as likely as women.
 * From 2005–2008, estimated diagnoses of HIV infection increased approximately 17% among MSM. This increase was likely due to a combination of factors: increases in new infections, increased testing, and diagnosis earlier in the course of infection; it may also have been due to uncertainty in statistical models.
 * In 2008, an estimated 17,940 MSM were diagnosed with AIDS in the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and the US dependent areas—an increase of 6% since 2005.
 * By the end of 2007, an estimated 282,542 MSM with an AIDS diagnosis had died in the United States and 5 dependent areas.
 
 The high prevalence of HIV infection among MSM means they face a greater risk of being exposed to infection with each sexual encounter—especially as they get older

 http://www.cdc.gov/hiv/topics/msm/
 
 The fact sheet (PDF) can be found here.

You argue for education, when in reality it would be telling people what they already know. STD 'education' is nothing new for gay men. If they aren't abiding by it so far when they all already know this, why should we assume more of the same would make a difference? Anyway, I have no problem with more education as long as we as a society stop trying to take a 'say-anything-but-gay' approach when it comes to pointing out harmful problems. 
 You should also explain your term "anti-gayer". That's another one of those things that is often just a rhetorical throw-around term.

 see, you would think that everyone knows already, but according to what you posted, 44% of HIV positive gay men were not educated about the dangers of unprotected sex. what you proposed is that they should stop being promiscuous, but who cares? if they understand the dangers of unprotected sex and learn to use condoms every time, it wont matter if they are promiscuous or not, their HIV stats will decrease. again, nearly half of the people infected with HIV werent properly educated on condom use according to the statistics you posted.
 
 i say "anti-gayers" because i suck in terms of making up words for things, and i know homophobic doesnt apply to everyone who's against homosexuality, and people dont like that word. by "anti-gayers" i mean the opposition to "pro-gayers".

see, you would think that everyone knows already, but according to what you posted, 44% of HIV positive gay men were not educated about the dangers of unprotected sex.

 
 You really believe that? That there's any adult male or female left in the U.S. that doesn't know they can get STDs? I'm sorry, there's no way. Any such stat is either misreported or the participants are not being honest.
 
 
what you proposed is that they should stop being promiscuous, but who cares? if they understand the dangers of unprotected sex and learn to use condoms every time, it wont matter if they are promiscuous or not, their HIV stats will decrease.

 
 The problem with promiscuity is that it's a playing-the-odds game even with protection. Sooner or later someone will give into temptation even though they don't have a condom with them or some condom (sooner or later) will fail or be defective. Why take the risk? Why not just admit promiscuity is not a good thing? Look, here's the issue--the gay pride movement argues that 'harm' should be the standard for whether or not gay-sex is moralistic; I would argue that the stats indicated that MSM clearly IS harmful. I think when the STD rate gets anywhere NEAR comparable between the two, they will have a point. Until then, I don't see why they would want to argue 'harm' as a standard. 
 
 One argument often made in response to this point is that in other countries, the incidence of HIV is higher among heterosexuals than gays. But there are clear outside factors at work there that would skew those stats, such as a less robust reporting system and in many countries less likelihood of anyone reporting gay activity at ALL (such as African countries where the incidence of HIV cases would probably be almost always reported as heterosexual even if, in actuality, it was homosexual). 
 
 The other argument often made to this is that MSM only applies to, well, men. IOW, lesbians don't have the HIV stats issue, for obvious reasons. That is a good point, and one could argue that the same STD harm factor does not seem to apply in the same significance when it comes to lesbianism. Of course my view is that harm should be the only factor for determining morality, but since the gay movement argues harm as the main factor, the issue of MSM stats presents major problems to their view.
 
 
i say "anti-gayers" because i suck in terms of making up words for things, and i know homophobic doesnt apply to everyone who's against homosexuality, and people dont like that word. by "anti-gayers" i mean the opposition to "pro-gayers".

 
 Well the problem with a term like 'anti-gayer' is that it implies automatically being against gay people when that's often not the case. (the issue is often that they are against same-gender sex, based on religion.) 'Course people in that movement tend to always WANT to portray those who take the religious issue on the behavior as being against the person. It's a disingenuous misrepresentation of many religious peoples' arguments, so that's why I usually ask people to qualify those sort of terms. If someone said "anti-gay sexual behavior" I might be ok with it.

The govt. has regulated cigarette smoking for ages, Accipiter. It hasn't fallen on churches to fight the issue of smoking because public policy has long already done so. The real hypocrisy in your example is that public policy acknowledges the harm in smoking, but is too cowardly to do so when it comes to MSM.

 i know you had some other points, but id like to reply to one in particular - promiscuity. the reason why i dont think it is your business to tell these people who they can and cannot sleep with is because people with a certain lifestyle should not be lectured by others with a different lifestyle. i understand what youre saying, that it is an issue of public concern, and that is very true, however getting people to change their lifestyle - more than that, their sexual behavior, is a) not going to work and b) morally wrong, and quite perverted. i agree, morals should be based on harm, but not only physical harm. it is morally wrong to change a person's lifestyle because then the person is not "allowed" to be themselves, but has to fit into the lifestyle set by someone else. that is an issue of public concern, too, and as i see it, an issue against their individual freedom to have consensual, adult sex with whoever they please.
 
 there really isnt a point to arguing that condoms wont always work... they are as close to 100% effective as possible, if used correctly. teaching people why it is important to use condoms, AND how to use them properly (banana demonstration emoticon_xgood ) would significantly reduce the HIV infections amongst sexually active people, far more than attempting to change people's sexual behaviors.
 
 i will refer you to one informative, educational television program you should check out - Jersey Shore on MTV. these people are A-OK, i see no thread outlining HIV statistics of 2X year old Italian-Americans. Straight people are awfully promiscuous too, in certain circles.

I just recently read reports that oral sex (by men on women, mostly) is responsible for a large increase in HPV related esophageal cancer (along with other head and neck cancers). 
 
 It's obvious to me that any kind of sexual interaction between anyone needs to be outlawed and all reproduction should be catered to by in vitro fertilization. Surgical procedures should be done to ensure that no sexual pleasure can be had. Say goodbye to unwanted pregnancies, abortions, and eventually STDs will nearly disappear... Overpopulation and poverty will be greatly diminished as well. 
 
 Or... the government can stay out of the bedroom and do a better job of sexual education to gay and straight people, and make condoms more readily available. The fact is that straight sex is responsible for abortions, divorces, the spread of diseases, and many other things, and I would guarantee that there are more promiscuous straight people than gay people (gays are at a big disadvantage, number-wise). 
 
 Straight and gay sex will always exist. Education is the answer to help solve these problems... Blaming gays doesn't help anyone.

 Adultery/cheating is a completely different thing. It is dishonesty and the breaking of a commitment. 
 
 Sexual behavior that is immoral and unacceptable would be cheating, rape, and sex with any person (or animal) that isn't capable of giving consent (children, etc... I guess this also falls under the category of rape, but in a different sense.) 
 
 Anything that consenting adults want to do sexually is their business. That's not to say they shouldn't be responsible, though.

 So in your view, the determinant for morality is only 'consent'? Interesting. Problem with that is, how do you determine what qualifies for consent. Age of consent laws, for instance, are very arbitrary. Some states won't let a 17 year old get married, even though there are plenty of 17 year olds more capable if good judgment than 18 year olds. There are numerous ways marriage discriminates, but of course we never hear about that from gay pride groups.

 So if marriage discriminates against one group of people, then that justifies discrimination against another?
 
 By the way, people under the age of consent CAN get married; they just need parental consent (I'm pretty sure it's like that in every state). That doesn't really sound unreasonable to me, and definitely not discrimination... You can use the same reasoning for drinking/smoking/driving/owning a firearm, etc. (Actually I do think it's unreasonable that a person can be old enough to be drafted into the military, but not old enough to drink a beer). There has to be an age limit in the law for these things... A case-by-case "maturity ruling" for every teenager isn't a reasonable option for it. 
 
 As far as the age thing goes, if it's illegal or you feel guilty about how young your partner is, you should avoid it. The whole point is that taking advantage of someone is wrong.
